# Introduction to Exoplanets ðŸŒ

Welcome to **Exoplanets** - worlds beyond our solar system!

## What you'll learn:
- **Detection Methods** - How we find exoplanets
- **Habitable Zones** - Where life might exist
- **Exoplanet Atmospheres** - What they're made of
- **Notable Exoplanets** - Key discoveries

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** As of 2023, we've discovered over 5,500 confirmed exoplanets!

## Definition

Exoplanet = Planet orbiting a star other than our Sun

## Brief History

| Year | Milestone |
|------|----------|
| 1992 | First exoplanets (pulsar planets) |
| 1995 | First around Sun-like star (51 Peg b) |
| 2009 | Kepler mission launches |
| 2016 | Proxima Centauri b discovered |
| 2017 | TRAPPIST-1 system (7 planets!) |
| 2018 | TESS mission launches |
| 2021 | JWST for atmospheres |

## Types of Known Exoplanets

| Type | Size | Examples |
|------|------|----------|
| Hot Jupiters | Jupiter-sized | 51 Peg b |
| Super-Earths | 1.25-2Ã— Earth | Kepler-442b |
| Mini-Neptunes | 2-4Ã— Earth | Many common |
| Earth-sized | ~Earth | TRAPPIST-1e |

Let's discover distant worlds!

### What we learn:
- Planet size (from dip depth)
- Orbital period
- Atmospheric composition (transmission spectroscopy)

### Limitations:
- Requires edge-on orbit
- Only ~1% of systems aligned
- Used by: Kepler, TESS

## 2. Radial Velocity (Doppler)

Planet's gravity tugs star â†’ Star wobbles â†’ Light shifts.


### What we learn:
- Minimum planet mass
- Orbital period
- Orbital eccentricity

## 3. Direct Imaging

Actually photograph the planet!

- Very difficult (star is ~1 billion Ã— brighter)
- Works for young, hot, distant planets
- Coronagraphs block starlight

## 4. Gravitational Microlensing

Planet+star bend light from background star.

## Detection Summary

| Method | Detections | Strength |
|--------|------------|----------|
| Transit | ~4,000 | Size, atmospheres |
| Radial velocity | ~1,000 | Mass |
| Direct imaging | ~50 | Physical properties |
| Microlensing | ~200 | Distant planets |

slides.content:
# The Habitable Zone ðŸŒ¡ï¸

The "Goldilocks Zone" - not too hot, not too cold.

## Definition

Region around a star where liquid water could exist on a planet's surface.

```
    TOO HOT â”‚ HABITABLE â”‚ TOO COLD
            â”‚   ZONE    â”‚

            â”‚   ðŸŒ      â”‚
            â”‚           â”‚
```

## HZ Boundaries

| Star Type | Inner Edge | Outer Edge |
|-----------|------------|------------|
| M dwarf | 0.1-0.2 AU | 0.2-0.4 AU |
| K star | 0.5 AU | 0.9 AU |
| G (Sun) | 0.95 AU | 1.4 AU |
| F star | 1.5 AU | 2.5 AU |

## Factors Affecting Habitability

### Stellar Factors
- Star type and temperature
- Stellar activity (flares)
- Stellar age

### Planetary Factors
- Atmosphere composition
- Greenhouse effect
- Plate tectonics
- Magnetic field
- Water availability

## Beyond the "Simple" HZ

| Concept | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Conservative HZ | Strict limits |
| Optimistic HZ | Extended limits |
| Subsurface habitability | Europa, Enceladus |
| Atmospheric effects | Venus vs Mars |

## M Dwarfs: Pros and Cons

| Pros | Cons |
|------|------|
| Most common stars | Tidal locking |
| Long-lived | Stellar flares |
| HZ closer (easier detection) | Close-in planets |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Habitability is more complex than just distance from star!

# Notable Exoplanets ðŸŒŸ

## Proxima Centauri b

- Closest known exoplanet (4.2 ly)
- Earth-mass, in habitable zone
- Orbits red dwarf
- Concerns: Stellar flares

## TRAPPIST-1 System

```
    TRAPPIST-1 (M dwarf)

    7 Earth-sized planets!

```

## Kepler-186f

- First Earth-sized planet in HZ
- Rocky composition likely
- 500 light-years away

## Kepler-452b

- "Earth's cousin"
- G-star (Sun-like)
- 385-day orbit
- 60% larger than Earth

## Hot Jupiters

| Planet | Star | Temperature |
|--------|------|-------------|
| 51 Peg b | 51 Pegasi | ~1,200 K |
| HD 209458b | HD 209458 | ~1,200 K |
| WASP-12b | WASP-12 | ~2,500 K |

## Extremes

| Record | Planet |
|--------|--------|
| Hottest | KELT-9b (~4,600 K) |
| Coldest | OGLE-2016-BLG-1195Lb (~50 K) |
| Densest | K2-229b (like Mercury) |
| Least dense | Kepler-51 planets (cotton candy) |
| Oldest system | Kepler-444 (11 billion years) |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Exoplanets show incredible diversity - unlike our solar system!
